data.title: HTML Nested Comments
data.body:
Is there any setting or package out there that can help with nested comments in HTML? ``` html
``` I want to quickly comment out everything, including the existing comments that mark the end of the divs: ``` html ``` I had to create a [package](https://github.com/philsinatra/HTML-Nest-Comments) for this functionality in Sublime Text. Using the ~~ is not a requirement (I borrowed the idea from BBEdit which supports this natively). I teach at Drexel University and we try to get our beginners in the habit of using comments frequently in their code, but we definitely don't want to waste time when we need to block comment something that already has comments. Any insight is greatly appreciated.

data.title: Cannot set syntax from command prompt.
data.body: I would imagine that pressing `cmd-shift-P`/`Ctrl+Shift+P` would allow me to set the current file's syntax directly by typing e.g. `javascript`. Or at least `cmd-shift-P`/`Ctrl+Shift+P`, then `syntax` or `language`, then `javascript`. But instead, it's hidden in `Ctrl+Shift+L`. Syntax changing should be accessible from the command palette.

data.title: per-buffer configuration
data.body: The editorconfig project uses file-path based rules to manage editor settings, but atom only has language-scoped settings. So, editorconfig can't manage settings like [trim_trailing_whitespace](https://github.com/sindresorhus/atom-editorconfig/issues/3) or [insert_final_newline](https://github.com/sindresorhus/atom-editorconfig/issues/4).

data.title: Regex select all <span> in html
data.body: I am trying use the replace to remove all `` in my html, for this I am using `<\s*\/?\s*span\s*.*?>`, However this regex just selecting all text together, the same is not true in the sublime, selecting only the `` as I need. I believe it is a problem in atom 0.187.0. Excuse the English, I'm using "google translate" to translate this text.

data.title: Backup improvement : prefer ~/.config/atom/ and ~/.local/shared/atom/ instead of ~/.atom/
data.body:
It would be nice to split .atom into .config/atom and .local/shared/atom (respectively AppData/Roaming and AppData/Local for Windows). There are more details on freedesktop.org spec for corresponding environment variable and use cases.

For example "compile-cache" would rather go to .local/shared and "snippets.cson, keymap.cson" to .config.

This clean separation would really help for backups (.local can usually be ignored, .config is important)

data.title: Unable to use atom as git commit editor on windows when an instance of atom is already running
data.body:
Setting atom as git editor on windows 7 works when I dont have an instance of atom running

```
> git config --global core.editor "atom --wait"
```

But when I am editing a file in atom and do a commit, I get below message even though the commit message tmp file opens in a new tab in current atom window.

```
> git commit
Aborting commit due to empty commit message.
>
```

data.title: Atom causes SourceTree to crash
data.body:
There is an issue on the SourceTree forums where Atom has been found to be the common factor in a crash on Windows:

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREEWIN-3040

It's also been mentioned in the squirrel repo which appears to be the real cause: https://github.com/Squirrel/Squirrel.Windows/pull/273

Apologies if this doesn't belong here as an issue.

data.title: Introduce a package dependency management system
data.body:
It's a nice to have feature, 'cause there's a lot of packages that depend on one another, for example, `minimap-git-diff` requires the `minmap` package, and a **lot** of packages require `autocomplete-plus` to work. If the dependent package(s) are not installed, not even a warning is showed to the user to install them.

So it'd be nice to have An API or something, that allows us to do something like

```
module.exports = MyPackage = 
  activate: ->
    atom.waitForDeps(['autocomplete-plus', 'minimap']) =>
      .. load the rest of it
```

or maybe

```
module.exports = MyPackage = 
  deps: ['autocomplete-plus', 'minimap']
  activate: ->
   .. do the stuff
```

I personally prefer the second one. I initially thought of creating a package for this purpose, but because that means that the packages that load before that package won't have that global variable means that they won't be able to access it and it will also be a bit un-cool.

data.title: Upgrade to pathwatcher 4.3
data.body:
Upgrade core, core libraries, and core packages to use pathwatcher 4.x which had some breaking changes from 3.x such as a `Sync` suffix to methods on `File`.

Closes #5706

data.title: Soft wrap hanging indentation spaces
data.body:
Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6003

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: Command line doesn't work in Windows
data.body:
After installing the latest version from the website (v0.187.0) on Windows 7 neither `atom` nor `apm` commands work in the command line. Restarting windows didn't seem to fix it.

Making `atom` work from command line I know how to do: add the weird folder that atom is installed in to the PATH, but I don't seem to find the `apm` executable.

data.title: Expand Selection To Tag
data.body: Are there any plans to add an option to Expand Selection To Tag, similar to a default option available in Sublime Text? I'm hoping to find out if it's in the future plans for Atom before spending time developing a package for this functionality.

data.title: :racehorse: Don't tokenize on NullGrammar
data.body:
For file format that Atom doesn't recognize as a
programming language, such as log files,
skip Tokenization since no syntax highlighting should be done.

data.title: Atom doesn't use snippets in the snippets folder ~/.atom/snippets
data.body:
I moved working snippets from the _~/.atom/snippets.cson_ file to new individual cson files in the snippets folder in _~/.atom/snippets_ (which I had to create) and they stopped working.

**Atom Version**: 0.187.0

data.title: Documentation: workspace.open( ) with no URI
data.body:
I just learned that [calling open on workspace](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-can-we-help-you-write-packages/4268/67) without specifying an uri is the way to go for getting a new tab with a new document. 

I can't find anything about this in either the docs or the [api documentation.](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.187.0/Workspace#instance-open)

Should `uri` be marked optional, like the `options` params? And should it be added a line stating that no uri opens a blank editor?

(and there's an extra `a` in the title..)

data.title: Add option for hanging indent for soft-wrapped lines.
data.body:
Please consider adding an option for hanging indents for soft-wrapped lines. It's really helpful for identifying wrapped lines, especially for languages like LaTeX where lines tend to be long and frequent editing makes manual hard wrapping needlessly tedious.

Example (adapted from @AlexLog's nicely-done example from Discuss): 

``` latex

% Current behavior
\begin{itemize}
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
    aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
    aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
\end{itemize}

% Proposed behavior with 4-space hanging indent specified
\begin{itemize}
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
        aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
    \item Aaaa aaa aaa aaaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa aaaaaa
        aaa aaaa aaaaaa aaa.
\end{itemize}

```

I'd add a variable to the soft wrap indent formula whose value is added to the indent level of the first line. By default, the value could be zero. In the UI, it should be on the `Settings` tab below `Tab Length` and named `Soft Wrap Hanging Indent`. If it uses a dropdown list like `Tab Length`, the options could be the same as the tab length options with the default zero option added.

While it could be designed as adding a configurable number of tab stops, it may be simpler to just make it a number of spaces, as there may be people who want a hanging indent level to be distinct from tab stops. Since the default would be zero, any level would have to be configured, so the number of spaces option would be no more configuration effort and more flexible.

Related discussions:

Discuss thread: https://discuss.atom.io/t/indented-soft-wrap/4808/1
Indent soft wrap (PR, Merged): https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/5567

data.title: Enable jumping between menus using left-right arrow keys
data.body:
If there is no sub-menu to a menu-entry, I would like to switch to the next menu when I press the left/right arrow keys. Also when I'm on the last nesting level in a sub-menu, I'd like to switch to the next main menu entry. If the said feature already exists it does not work for me on Ubuntu 14.04 using Atom version 0.187.0.

To clarify what I'm saying:

![zhhmfqqzcz](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5445560/6683412/0d669cf4-ccac-11e4-9181-398ea6be26e8.png)

In the above scenario, I would like to be able to switch to the "Selection" menu when I press the right arrow key, other than when I press it on the "developer" menu-entry, which will open the sub-menu like it already does. However, inside the developer sub-menu also pressing the right arrow key does not take me to "Selection".

~~Another such issue is that once I've opened a menu with "alt+ ", say "View" with alt+V, I'm not able to open selection with "alt+S" unless I close the view menu first.~~

Thanks.

**EDIT**:- It's UbuntuMATE 14.04, so I'm in a MATE-desktop environment.
